abstract.p: Jose Manuel Santos fatally stabs his girlfriend Emilia Moise on empty Long Island Rail Road platform in Westbury after two argued over breaking up (S)

block.p: A man fatally stabbed his girlfriend early yesterday morning on an empty Long Island Rail Road platform in Westbury after the two argued over breaking up, the police said.

The man, Jose Manuel Santos, 38, repeatedly stabbed Emilia Moise, 24, in the neck, using a folding knife with a three-inch blade, after he told her he wanted to break up with her, said Detective Sgt. William Cocks of the Nassau County police.
A man fatally stabbed his girlfriend early yesterday morning on an empty Long Island Rail Road platform in Westbury after the two argued over breaking up, the police said.

The man, Jose Manuel Santos, 38, repeatedly stabbed Emilia Moise, 24, in the neck, using a folding knife with a three-inch blade, after he told her he wanted to break up with her, said Detective Sgt. William Cocks of the Nassau County police.

The argument broke out around 12:30 a.m. on the eastbound platform of the station, shortly after the two, who had just left work in a nearby restaurant, had had sex in a dark tunnel beneath the platforms, Sergeant Cocks said. ''They walk routinely to this station after work to do what they do,'' he said.
Mr. Santos, of Hicksville, was arrested shortly after the killing and charged with second-degree murder. He was arraigned yesterday and held without bail at the Nassau County jail.

Ms. Moise, of Westbury, had worked as a cashier for six years and Mr. Santos as a cook for seven years at Nathan's, a hot dog restaurant on Old Country Road in Westbury. The two had been dating for three years, the police said.
But managers at Nathan's said they did not know the two were involved.
''She's a very nice person,'' said Angelo Cordoro, the assistant manager there. ''I can't picture that in my head, that really happening.''

Miguel Mendoza, the manager, said Mr. Santos had told him that he had a wife and five children in El Salvador and that he was sending money to support them. ''It was a surprise to me,'' Mr. Mendoza said. ''He looked like a quiet guy, a nice guy.''
On May 20, Mr. Santos and Ms. Moise got into an argument at Ms. Moise's home, prompting her to call the police, the authorities said. There were no arrests.
